The king asked again, Is there no one who surpasses the Buddha? NÃ¢gasena said, Indeed, there is no one who surpasses the Buddha.
How do you know that there is no one who surpasses the Buddha?
If a person has never entered the great ocean, how can he know that the seawater is great?

There are five rivers, each with five hundred small rivers flowing into the great river. The first is called Ganges, the second is called Sindhu, the third is called Vaksu, the fourth is called Sita, and the fifth is called Eulava.
The waters of these five rivers flow day and night into the ocean, yet the seawater neither increases nor decreases.
Can the king hear and know this?
Because those who have attained the Way speak of the Dharma together, and no one can surpass the Buddha, therefore I have faith in him.
How do you know that no one can surpass the Buddha?
Who was the creator of writing?
The creator of writing was named Qi.
Qi died long ago, I have never seen him.
Since you have never seen Qi, how do you know that Qi was the creator of writing?
The ancient writings and characters have been passed down to us. For this reason, I know him as Qi.
For this reason, we see the sutras and precepts of the Buddha as if we were seeing the Buddha himself, no different.
The Buddha's teachings are profound and excellent. People who understand the Buddha's precepts will then teach each other. For this reason, I know that there is no one who can surpass the Buddha.
You have seen the Buddha's teachings that can be practiced for a long time.
The Buddha's teachings and precepts are excellent. I will uphold and practice them until old age.
After a person dies, does their body not follow to the next life?
After a person dies, they take on a new body, so the old body does not follow.
It is like a candle wick burning itself out, the old wick is still there, but a new wick burns again.
A person's body is like this. The old body does not go, but takes on a new body.
When you were young, did you learn to read and study scriptures from a teacher?
The teacher from whom the king received the scriptures, does the teacher still know the original scriptures?
All the old scriptures were obtained from the original scriptures.
The teacher continues to know the original scriptures himself.
The human body is like this, discarding the old and receiving a new body.
Is it really wise or not?
For example, if a person steals someone else's fruits and vegetables, is the thief guilty or not?
When the plants were first planted, there were no fruits or vegetables. Why would the thief be guilty?ğŸ”½The king said:
If you don't plant, how can there be fruit?
Therefore, a thief has no case.
Using the good and evil done in this world, they are reborn in the next world and receive a new body.
Why do people use this body to do good and evil, and where do the new good and evil come from?
Whatever people do, good and evil follow them, like a shadow follows the body.
When a person dies, they only lose their body, not their actions.
It's like writing at night by fire, when the fire goes out the characters remain, and when the fire returns it completes them.
The actions done in this world are completed in the next world, and one receives them accordingly.
Can NÄgasena distinguish and point out where good and evil are?
The location of good and evil cannot be known.
Before the trees have fruit, can one distinguish and point to them, saying that there are no fruits among their branches?
Can one know this in advance or not?
People who have not attained the Way cannot know in advance where good and evil are.
Can those who are to be reborn in the next world know this by themselves or not?
Those who are to be reborn can know it by themselves.
What use is there in knowing it?
It is like a farmer who plows and plants, and the rain falls on time. Can that person know in advance that he will obtain grain or not?
I still know that I will obtain much grain.
People should know in advance where they will be reborn in their next life.
Is there really nirvÄá¹‡a or not?
Can you point out to me where the Buddha is?
I cannot point out where the Buddha is.
After the Buddha entered parinirvÄá¹‡a, his whereabouts cannot be indicated.
It's like someone lighting a large fire, and then extinguishing it. Can you point out where the light went?
I cannot know where it went.
After the Buddha entered parinirvÄá¹‡a, his whereabouts cannot be known.
Do Å›ramaá¹‡as love their own bodies or not?
The Å›ramaá¹‡a does not love his own body.
If the Å›ramaá¹‡a does not love his own body, why does he seek comfort in rest, desire delicious and soft food, and take good care of himself? Why is it so?
Have you ever entered into battle?
Have you ever been struck by a sword or arrow in battle?
I have indeed been struck by a sword.
What about the wounds from the sword and arrows?
I wrap them with ointment, cotton, and bandages.
Do you wrap them with ointment, cotton, and bandages out of love for the wounds?
I do not love the wound.
If one does not love the wound, why wrap it with ointment and cotton to protect it?
I want it to heal quickly, I do not love the wound.

They do not love the body, although they eat and drink, they do not enjoy it, they do not use it to make themselves beautiful, they do not use it to make themselves good-looking, they do not use it to make their complexion ruddy, they just want to sustain the body and practice the Buddha's sutras and precepts.
People have nine orifices, which are like nine spear wounds, and all the orifices are foul-smelling and impure.
Does the Buddha really have thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, a body that is golden in color with radiance?
The Buddha indeed has thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, all with a golden color and radiance.
Do the Buddha's parents also have the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, with bodies of golden color and radiance?
The Buddha's parents do not have these marks.
If the parents do not have these marks, then the Buddha also does not have these marks.
When a person gives birth to a child, it resembles its kind.
If the parents do not have these marks, then the Buddha definitely does not have these marks.
Although the Buddha's parents do not have the thirty-two marks, eighty minor marks, and a golden-colored body, the Buddha indeed has these marks.
Have you ever seen a lotus flower?
Nagasena said:ğŸ”½The lotus flower grows in the mud, yet it is pure and clean, without any filth.
This lotus flower grows in the ground and is nurtured by mud and water. Its color is very fragrant and beautiful. Does it resemble the color of the mud and water?
It does not resemble the color of the ground or mud and water.
Although the Buddha's parents did not have these characteristics, the Buddha indeed had these characteristics.
The Buddha was born in the world and grew up in the world, but he did not resemble worldly affairs.
Is it true that the Buddha did not engage in sexual intercourse with women, like the Brahma of the seventh heaven?
He was indeed free from women, pure and spotless.
If the Buddha acted like the king of the seventh heaven, then the Buddha would be a disciple of the Brahma of the seventh heaven.
Does the king of the seventh heaven have thoughts or not?
Is the seventh heaven king Brahma mindful?
Therefore, the seventh heaven king Brahma and the heavens above are all disciples of the Buddha.
What kind of sound does a bird make?
The sound of a bird is like the sound of a goose.
In that case, is the bird a disciple of the goose, or are they different species?
The Buddha is also like this, he is not a disciple of the seventh heaven king Brahma.
Did the Buddha study and know all the sutras and precepts?
The Buddha studied and knew all the sutras and precepts.
From whom did the Buddha receive the sutras and precepts?
When the Buddha attained the Way, he immediately knew all the sutras and paths by himself.
The Buddha is not as good as the disciples who learn and understand the Buddha's teachings. All the disciples will uphold and practice them until old age.
When a person's parents die, they cry and tears flow.
People also cry and tears flow when they hear the Buddha's sutras.
Are the tears that flow the same or different?
When people's parents cry, they all feel love and affection, and worry and grieve in pain.
Those who hear the Buddha's teachings and shed tears all have a compassionate heart, thinking of the hardships in the world, and therefore shed tears. The merit they obtain is very great.
What are the differences between those who have attained liberation and those who have not?
Those who have not yet attained liberation have a mind of greed, those who have attained liberation have no mind of greed, they just want to obtain food to sustain their lives.
I see that people in the world all want to indulge their bodies and obtain delicious food, they are never satisfied.
Those who have not yet attained liberation use food and drink to create glory and pleasure.
Those who have attained liberation, although they eat and drink, do not take it as pleasure or sweetness, they just want to sustain their lives.
Do people think of things from long ago when they do something?
When people are sad, they all think of things from long ago.
What do they think of?ğŸ”½Do they think of it with their mind?
Or do they think of it with their thoughts?
Have you ever learned something and then forgotten it later?
I have learned something, but later I have forgotten it.
At that time, did you forget without forgetting?
At that time, my thoughts were false.
It is possible, Your Majesty, you have an elephant.
When people do something, do they all think, as if they are doing something for the first time now?
Things that have already happened are all known through memory, and things that are happening now are also known through memory.
In this way, a person only remembers past events and cannot remember new things.
If the new is something that cannot be remembered, it is the same.
Is it a waste of time for a beginner to learn calligraphy?
When a person first learns to write, they have thoughts, and in order to teach their disciples, they have thoughts.
How many things do people use to give rise to thoughts?
People generally have sixteen things that give rise to thoughts.

First, remembering what was done long ago; second, remembering what was learned recently; third, remembering when there was a great matter; fourth, remembering thinking of goodness; fifth, remembering past suffering; sixth, remembering thinking by oneself; seventh, remembering past mixed deeds; eighth, remembering teaching others; ninth, remembering images; tenth, remembering what was once forgotten; eleventh, remembering due to recognition; twelfth, remembering from calculation; thirteenth, remembering debts; fourteenth, remembering with single-mindedness; fifteenth, remembering reading books; sixteenth, remembering what was once entrusted and seeing it again, remembering these sixteen things.
First, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by long-term memory?
The Buddha's disciple Ä€nanda and his female disciple UpÄsikÄ KuÅ›anÄ, remembering the events of a billion past lives.
And other practitioners of the Way can all recall past events.
Like Ä€nanda's many female disciples, they recall this and are able to remember.
What is meant by newly learned thoughts arising?
It is like a person who has learned accounting but later forgets it. Seeing others doing accounting, they recall it again.
Third, the king asked NÄgasena again:
What is meant by thoughts arising from great matters?
It is like a prince being enthroned as king. He thinks to himself that being a king is glorious and noble, which is a thought arising from a great matter.
Fourth, the king asked NÄgasena again:
What is meant by thoughts of good intentions arising?
It is like when a person is invited by others with utmost good intentions and hospitality. That person thinks to themselves:
In the past, I was invited by so-and-so with good intentions and treated well.
This is called thinking of good things and giving rise to thoughts.
Fifth, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by thinking of suffering and giving rise to thoughts?
It is like a person who has been beaten and imprisoned by others. This is called thinking of suffering and giving rise to thoughts.
Sixth, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by thinking of oneself and giving rise to thoughts?
It is like having seen something before, such as one's family, relatives, or animals. This is called thinking of oneself and giving rise to thoughts.
Seventh, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by thinking of past actions and giving rise to thoughts?
It is like a person who remembers the names, categories, colors, smells, sweetness, and bitterness of myriad things. Thinking of these things is called giving rise to miscellaneous thoughts.
Eighth, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by thinking of teaching people and giving rise to thoughts?
People themselves are prone to forget, but those around them may remember or forget. This is taught to help people remember.
Ninth, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by 'recollection of images'?
People, cows, and horses each have their own images, this is called the recollection of images.
Tenth, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by 'recollection of what was forgotten'?
For example, if a person suddenly forgets something, they repeatedly think about it alone and can retrieve it, this is called the recollection of what was forgotten.
Eleventh, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by 'recollection arising from recognition'?
When learning to write, one can seek out the characters, this is called the recollection arising from recognition.
Twelfth, the king asked Ä€nanda again:
What is meant by 'recollection arising from calculation'?
Ä€nanda replied:ğŸ”½For example, when counting money, one can know how much is missing or in excess, this is called the recollection arising from calculation.
It is like when people calculate together, they know everything that is accomplished, and the strategies are clear, this is called the thought of calculation.
What is meant by the thought of owing debts?
It is like looking back at the debts one should repay, this is called the thought of owing debts.
What is meant by the thought of single-mindedness?
When a Å›ramaá¹‡a unifies his mind and thinks to himself, 'The events of my past lives in the thousands of millions of worlds are all mine,' this is the thought of unifying the mind.
What is meant by the thought of reading books?
The king has ancient books, and he thinks, 'This book was written in such and such an emperor's reign,' this is called the thought of reading books.
What do you mean by saying that something entrusted to someone else may be seen and remembered again?
If a person entrusts something to someone else, and later sees it with their eyes, they will remember it. This is what is meant by something entrusted to someone else being remembered.
Does the Buddha know all past, present, and future events?
The Buddha knows all of them.
If the Buddha knows all events, why didn't he teach all his disciples at once?
Why did he teach them gradually?
Are there physicians in the country?
Do they know all the medicines in the world?
When a doctor treats a disease, does he give medicine all at once or gradually?
When a person is not sick, one cannot give them medicine in advance. Medicine is only given when there is a sickness.
Although the Buddha knows all past, present, and future events, he cannot teach all the people in the world all at once. He must gradually bestow the sutras and precepts and have them practice them.
When a person is in the world and does evil for a hundred years, but at the time of death they think of the Buddha, after death they will all be reborn in the heavens.
Kill one person, and upon death one will immediately enter the hells.
If a person holds a small stone and places it on the water, does the stone float or sink?
Suppose one were to place a hundred large stones on a boat, would the boat sink?
The hundred large stones in the boat do not sink because of the boat.
Although a person may have evil in their past, if they think of the Buddha for a moment, because of this they will not enter the hells, but will be reborn in the heavens.
The small stone that sinks is like a person who does evil and does not know the Buddha's teachings, after death they will enter the hells.
Why do you practice the path and become an ascetic?
I practice the path and become an ascetic in order to abandon the suffering of the past, present, and future, and do not wish to experience any more suffering.
Suffering comes in the next life, why study the Way in advance and become a monk?
Does your country have enemy states that want to attack you?
There are enemy states that always want to attack us.
When the enemy approaches, do you then prepare for battle, fortify your defenses, and dig moats?
Or do you prepare in advance?
You should have reserves prepared in advance.
For what reason do you prepare in advance?
Because the enemy's arrival has no fixed time.
Since the enemy has not yet come, why prepare in advance?
Do you plant fields when hungry and dig wells when thirsty?
You should prepare all of these in advance.
I am not yet hungry or thirsty, why make preparations in advance?
How far is it from the seventh Brahma Heaven?
If you were to drop a stone the size of the king's hall from the seventh Brahma Heaven, it would take six months and six days to fall to the ground here.
That attaining the state of an arhat is like the time it takes to bend and extend one's arm, and they can fly up to the seventh Brahma Heaven.
How can it be so fast to travel millions and millions of miles?
In what country were you originally born?
I was originally born in the Great Qin country, named Alichan.
How many miles is it from here to Asita?
It is two thousand yojanas, which is eighty thousand li.
Have you ever thought of the affairs of your homeland from afar?
I always think of the affairs in my homeland.
Your Majesty, please think again of the affairs in your homeland and what you have done.
I have already thought of it.
Your Majesty traveled eighty thousand li back and forth, why was it so fast?
If two people die here at the same time, one is reborn in the seventh Brahma heaven and the other is reborn in KaÅ›mÄ«ra, seven hundred and twenty li away, who will arrive first?
The two will arrive at the same time.
The distance between them is vast, how can they both arrive at the same time?
Try to think of the country of Arita.
I have already thought of it.
King, try to think of Kasmira again.
I have already thought of it.
Thinking of these two countries, which one is faster?
It is the same as if two people were to die at the same time, one being reborn in the seventh heaven of Brahma and the other being reborn in Kasmira.
If there were a pair of flying birds, one bird perched on a large tree and one bird perched on a small tree.
When the two birds perch, whose shadow would reach the ground first?
Their shadows would reach the ground at the same time.
Both people died, one was reborn in the seventh heaven of the Brahmas, and one was reborn in KÄÅ›i, both arriving at the same time.
How many things does a person use to study and understand the Way?
One studies and understands the Way using seven things.

First, remembering good and evil things; second, diligence; third, delighting in the Way; fourth, subduing the mind for goodness; fifth, contemplating the Way; sixth, single-minded focus; seventh, encountering without aversion or attachment.
Do people study and understand the Way using these seven things?
Not all study and understand the Way using seven things.
The wise use their wisdom to distinguish good and evil, and use this one thing to distinguish.
If one thing can be used to know, why speak of seven things?
If a person holds a knife in its sheath leaning against a wall, can the knife cut anything by itself?
Although the human mind is clear, it must rely on these six things to accomplish wisdom.
Is the merit of doing good deeds in a household great?
Is the harm of doing evil great?
The merit of doing good is great, and the harm of doing evil is small.
In a household, if one does evil but repents daily, then the harm is small.
In a household, if one does good and thinks of it day and night with joy, then the merit is great.
In the past, when the Buddha was in the world, there was a person in the country who had no hands or feet but picked lotus flowers and offered them to the Buddha.
The Buddha then told the monks:
'This person with no hands or feet will not fall into the hells, animal realm, or hungry ghost realm for ninety-one kalpas in the future, and will be reborn in the heavens.
When his life in the heavens ends, he will be reborn as a human again.'
Therefore, I know that a person who does a small good deed receives great blessings.
If a person commits an evil deed and repents, the transgression will dissipate and disappear over time. Therefore, I know that a person's misfortune from committing an offense is small.
If a wise person commits an evil deed and a foolish person commits an evil deed, which of these two people receives more misfortune?
A foolish person who commits an evil deed receives greater misfortune, while a wise person who commits an evil deed receives less misfortune.
I do not agree with what Ä€nanda said.
In the governance of my country, if a great minister commits an offense, the punishment is heavy, but if an ignorant commoner commits an offense, the punishment is light.
Therefore, a wise person who commits evil receives great misfortune, while a foolish person who commits evil receives little misfortune.

Suppose there is a piece of burning iron on the ground. One person knows it is burning iron, while another does not. If the two people both reach out to touch the burning iron, whose hand will be more severely burned?
The one who does not know will have his hand more severely burned.
A foolish person who commits evil cannot repent on his own, so his misfortune is great.
A wise person who commits evil knows it was wrong to do so and repents daily, so his misfortune is little.
Can a person carry this body and fly up to the seventh heaven of the Brahmas, and to the land of Uttarakuru, and to wherever they want to go?
How can one carry this body up to the seventh heaven of the Brahmas, and to the land of Uttarakuru, and to wherever they want to go?
Have you ever thought of jumping a distance of ten feet when you were a child?
When I was young, I thought of jumping, and I jumped more than ten feet.
The mind of one who has attained the Way wants to jump to the seventh heaven of the Brahmas, and to the land of Uttarakuru, and it is the same.
You Å›ramaá¹‡as say:ğŸ”½There are bones four thousand li long.
What kind of body bones are four thousand li long?
Have you heard of a giant fish in the great ocean named Tila, whose body is 28,000 li long?
If such a 28,000 li fish has rib bones 4,000 li long, what do you think of that, king?
'We can cut off the activity of breathing.'
How can one cut off the breath?
Have you ever heard of the mind?
Do you think the mind is in the human body?
I think the mind is in the human body.
The king thinks that foolish people cannot control their body and speech, cannot uphold the scriptures and precepts, and such people do not enjoy their own bodies.
Those who study the Way can control their body and speech, uphold the scriptures and precepts, unify their minds, attain the four dhyÄnas, and then they no longer breathe.
Is it called the ocean because the water is called the ocean?
Or is it called the ocean for other reasons?
The reason people call it the ocean is because the water and salt are mixed together equally, and therefore it is called the ocean.
Why is the ocean salty like salt?
NÄgasena said:ğŸ”½The reason is that the ocean is salty like salt is because the water and salt are mixed together equally.
The reason the seawater is salty is because of the accumulation of fresh water over a long period of time, and the many fish, turtles, and insects all defecate in the water, thus making it salty.
Can one who has attained the Way fully contemplate profound matters?
One who has attained the Way can fully contemplate profound matters.
The Buddha's teachings are the most profound, and they know all matters.
The immeasurable matters are all judged by wisdom.
Are the three things of human spirits, wisdom, and spontaneity the same or different?
Human spirits are born with awareness, the wise understand the Way, and spontaneity is empty space with no people.
What do you mean by 'attaining a human birth'?

The eyes see forms, the ears hear sounds, the nose smells fragrances, the mouth knows tastes, the body experiences smoothness, and the mind knows good and bad things - what does it mean to attain a human birth?

If a person is able to see with their eyes, but their eyeballs are removed, would their vision be wider and farther?ğŸ”½If their ears are torn open, would their hearing of sounds be wider and farther?
If their nose is cut open, would their sense of smell be greater?
If their mouth is opened wide, would their knowledge of tastes be greater?
If their skin is peeled off, would they be able to truly know smoothness?
If their mind is pulled out, would their thoughts be more numerous?
What the Buddha does is extremely difficult, and what the Buddha is like is extremely wonderful.
What is extremely difficult to do and what is extremely wonderful?

NÄgasena said:ğŸ”½The Buddha's body is like a mountain, his eyes are like the sun and moon, his ears are like the four seas, his nose is like a mountain, his mouth is like a well, his skin is like a city wall, his mind is like a great void, and his body is like a great mountain.
The Buddha can know what is in a person's belly and can understand all that the eyes see.
He can understand eye matters, ear matters, nose matters, mouth matters, body matters, failure matters, doubt matters, thought matters, and spirit matters.
If a person takes seawater and holds it in their mouth, can they distinguish which water in their mouth is spring water, which is flowing water, and which is river water?
All the waters are combined into one, and it is difficult to know each one separately.
What the Buddha does is difficult, and he can distinguish all the tastes of these waters.
Now, the seawater is seen, and the present matter, the king still cannot distinguish it. Now, the human spirit is invisible, and there are six invisible things in the human body.
NÄgasena said:ğŸ”½The Buddha can know the six invisible things in the human body.

Therefore, the Buddha understands it. From thoughts to what the eyes see, from thoughts to what the ears hear, from thoughts to what the nose smells, from thoughts to what the mouth tastes, from thoughts to what the body experiences as pain or pleasure, cold or warmth, coarse or firm, from thoughts to where they go, the Buddha knows and understands them all.
It's already midnight, I wish to leave.
The king then ordered his ministers:
Take four pieces of cotton cloth, soak them in sesame oil, and hold them as torches to see NÄgasena off.
Serve NÄgasena with the same respect as you serve me.
If one can have a teacher like NÄgasena and a disciple like me, one can quickly attain the Way.
The king asked various questions, and NÄgasena answered them one by one. The king was greatly delighted and gave NÄgasena a robe worth more than 100,000 from his own treasury.
From now on, I wish that you and 800 monks would have meals in the palace every day, and you can take whatever you need from the king.
I am a monk and have no desires.
NÄgasena should protect himself and also protect my body.
What does it mean to protect oneself and protect the king's body?
I am afraid people will discuss it and call the king stingy.
NÄgasena has resolved all the king's doubts, but he is not given anything.
I am afraid people will say:
NÄgasena is not able to resolve the king's doubts, so the king does not give him anything.
NÄgasena, the receiver should allow me to obtain its blessings, and NÄgasena should also protect its name.
It is like a lion in a golden cage, still confined, always wanting to leave.
Now, although I am the king of a country, in the palace, my mind is not happy, wanting to abandon the country and go practice the Way.
When the king finished speaking, NÄgasena then rose and returned to the Buddha's temple.
As soon as NÄgasena left, the king secretly thought to himself:ğŸ”½What kind of things did I ask NÄgasena?
What kind of things did NÄgasena explain to me?
Whatever I asked, NÄgasena did not fail to understand my meaning.
NÄgasena returned to the Buddha's temple and also thought to himself:
What kind of things did the king ask me?
What kind of things did I reply to the king?
Whatever the king asked, I also explained them all.
Thinking about this matter until dawn.
The next day, NÄgasena put on his robes, took his bowl, and went straight to the palace to sit in the hall. The king prostrated to NÄgasena and then sat back.
After you left, I thought to myself:ğŸ”½'What words will I ask NÄgasena?
What words will NÄgasena reply to me?'
'Whatever I ask NÄgasena, NÄgasena will surely understand my meaning.'
Thinking these words, I happily lay down until dawn.
When I returned home, I also thought to myself:
'What matters will the king ask me about?
What matters will I explain to the king?'
'Whatever the king asks, I will explain accordingly.'
For this reason, I was joyful until dawn.
When they finished speaking, NÄgasena wanted to leave, and the king immediately rose to pay homage to NÄgasena.
